awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  LookingBus: Improving Public Transportation Services for the Blind
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project is to develop an industry-ready service to improve public transportation for riders with disabilities, specifically visual impairments. The LookingBus technology helps drivers accommodate the needs of certain riders, while limiting distractions from their primary roles of driving safely. Individuals with visual impairments depend heavily on public transit as an essential service for daily life, social activities, and employment. However, they often face challenges with (1) finding the correct bus stop, (2) determining which bus to board, and (3) departing the bus at the right stop. By developing an advanced notification service for alerting bus drivers, LookingBus will address the societal and market needs to mitigate these challenges. The product will promote independent, confident use of public transportation for riders with visual impairments, which may also promote a greater opportunity to pursue and maintain employment. 

The proposed project will further develop and commercialize LookingBus, an industry-ready service to enhance public transportation experience for riders with disabilities, such as visual impairments. LookingBus provides an advanced notification system alerting drivers about riders at upcoming stops and their planned destinations. The proposed system will integrate a beacon at the bus stop with a display on the bus connected to an app on the user's mobile phone. This assures that riders with disabilities can safely utilize fixed-route public transportation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Overview

LookingBus, developed by ILANs, Inc. with support from the NSF SBIR program, is a smart city technology that addresses the "pass-by" challenge, which refers to incidents where riders are not picked up or not given enough time to exit at their desired stop. LookingBus alerts drivers when riders with disabilities are waiting to board or exit the bus, and it notifies riders via the mobile app when their bus is approaching and when it is time to get off. The LookingBus dashboard, developed with support from Phase IIB funding, effectively monitors the entire activity, including trip information and incidents. creation of the LookingBus system involves research and development of hardware (sensors) and software components (mobile app, driver app, dashboard, servers, and cloud application).

LookingBus targets bus agencies as its primary customers with a proprietary solution that reduces costs, enhances accessibility and rider experience for individuals with disabilities and all riders, and promotes sustainability, inclusivity, and safety. As public transit shifts to Zero Emission Buses (ZEBs), LookingBus becomes even more crucial. ZEBs are much quieter, posing significant challenges for those relying on auditory cues, resulting in a higher rate of pass-bys and leaving more passengers stranded at stops. LookingBus automated alerting system addresses these issues while prioritizing passenger safety and promoting inclusivity in modern transit.

All technical objectives of the project have been accomplished, strengthening the position for commercialization and future enhancements, which is a testament to the expertise and hard work of our team. These objectives encompassed a diverse set of goals, including developing new features and functionality, improving the user experience and interface, enhancing security and privacy, expanding location-aware sensor capabilities, designing new tools and resources for drivers and riders, and creating a dashboard to monitor and analyze key metrics.

Intellectual Merit

The Small Business Innovation Research Phase II project enhances the work of technology developers, researchers, and service providers by emphasizing the importance of connectivity among riders, drivers, and dispatch personnel to ensure safe and accessible fixed-route public transportation for riders with disabilities. The Findings also contribute to the existing literature on smart sensors and their role in achieving the Smart City vision. Furthermore, the project educates the community on strategies for training drivers and riders on the new technology and services, furthering understanding of challenges faced by riders with disabilities in public transportation and their impact on their lives.

Broader impact

The broader impact of this project was to develop an industry-ready technological solution to enhance public transportation for riders with disabilities, including those with visual impairments. The LookingBus technology equips drivers with a tool to address the needs of riders while prioritizing their primary responsibility of driving safely and efficiently for all passengers. LookingBus specifically addresses pass-by incidents, which restrict access to essential resources and services for individuals with disabilities, causing stress and financial strain on families and compromising productivity and healthcare. Addressing pass-by incidents is crucial to ensure that individuals with disabilities can fully participate in society and access the resources and services they need. This, in turn, enhances transportation accessibility, benefitting not only individuals and their families but also creating a more inclusive and thriving society by expanding work opportunities and enhancing the economy. Additionally, the LookingBus system ensures that riders with disabilities are not excluded from modernization, such as the shift to Zero Emission buses, promoting sustainability and accessibility.

 


Last Modified: 05/31/2023
Modified by: Yariv Glazer
